What does everyone think is the best board game of all time?
 I have a poll but it is limited with the number of board games out there. I think I listed the possible essentual ones.
 My opinion is on The Game Of Life.
Okay, so no one else likes board games except for one person who only felt like voting for one. That's fair.

I have to say Monopoly. I've had some pretty memorable games with my friends with this game. It seems there's just the right amount of strategy, and the right amount of chance, and the right amount of freedom, being able to barter and deal the way you want with the other player.

Chess is the best, by far.
 Monopoly comes in 2nd.
 Yahtzee comes in 3rd (One you missed)
 Nude Twister comes in when the lights are out!emoticon_xclown

Chess is the best, by far.
 Monopoly comes in 2nd.
 Yahtzee comes in 3rd (One you missed)
 Nude Twister comes in when the lights are out!emoticon_xclown

 I never really consided Yahtzee as a board game. If it is, I think it would go under "other." Isn't it more so played with dice and a cup? If not, I guess I've just always played it wrong. I think of board games as coming with a hard board to play on. So if Yahtzee is one of those, than I guess I never really played it corectly.

Chess, hands down.

 
 Have to agree with that. All skill and no luck.
Monopoly just because chess gives me a headache...Monopoly is pretty relaxing.

I never really consided Yahtzee as a board game. If it is, I think it would go under "other." Isn't it more so played with dice and a cup? If not, I guess I've just always played it wrong. I think of board games as coming with a hard board to play on. So if Yahtzee is one of those, than I guess I never really played it corectly.

 Technically, you are correct. However, you need the cup, the dice, the scorepads and a BOARD to throw the dice onto!emoticon_xclown

Have to agree with that. All skill and no luck.
...except that sometimes your opponent's oversight is your good luck.

I would rate chess as the best board game, but I quit playing years ago because it became a bored game. Speaking of games, several years ago I was talking with a programmer friend and he asked me if I had ever played Free Cell on my PC. I told him no and he explained that it was a simple game with over 32,000 combinations and he wasn't sure they could all be won. That evening I looked up the game and started to play with game 1. I don't know if they can all be won, but as of today I know that the first 9,922 can be.
 Dono

I honestly never got into chess. I think I tried to once and who ever was telling me about it just got me loss. How you can accurately move your pawn (not to mention the correct pawn) on the board from one square to a completely different one and everything was just awkward in my head. Now checkers, I can understand. You can only move to an adjacent square. All pieces of one color are equal unless one is kinged. It seemed to me at one time that chess and checkers were the same game in a way but that one was sort of a poor-man's version of the other. But to me it just seems that chess gets more involved.
 
 Now as I said in my first post was that I chose the game of Life. My reason for that was that it was my favorite childhood game. I just always enjoied playing LIFE.

It seemed to me at one time that chess and checkers were the same game in a way but that one was sort of a poor-man's version of the other. But to me it just seems that chess gets more involved.
 

 
 I wouldn't compare checkers and chess. I think one has play chess for a period of time, understand and employ some of the classic openings and then be beaten by a master with a few simple moves to understand how complicated chess is.

I wouldn't compare checkers and chess. I think one has play chess for a period of time, understand and employ some of the classic openings and then be beaten by a master with a few simple moves to understand how complicated chess is.

 I wasn't saying that I was compairing them. I said that I use to think they were the same thing. Maybe it was the whole royalty thing. In checkers, if you make it to the end of the board, you get kinged. In chess, you have a king...
 Remember, I said that this was when I was younger. However, would it make more sence to compare it to a game like RISK on some level? Aren't they both a game of war where you need to protect your (what ever you have) by sending your men over?
 Okay, honestly, I've never played either. I've tried to understand them but the other games that I listed on the poll just make more sence to me (Like LIFE, Clue, Monopoly, Checkers.) But I thought they both had a fairly good following so I added them (I see Chess does.) So tell you what, I won't go trying to compair chess with anything else.

... So tell you what, I won't go trying to compare chess with anything else.
A wise decision as chess is in a league of its own. I can think of no other board game that requires equal skills.

For the most people who have posted on here and say that chess is the best, I was wondering if there were any personal reasons for preferring chess. I say this because how I'm reading them makes it sound like a private or prep-school "I wear a suit and play chess in a club and I will get graded down if I don't say I like chess," kind of dry, robotic responses. The closes to any actually feeling I got was...
 
I would rate chess as the best board game, but I quit playing years ago because it became a bored game.

 That is basically the concept I get from reading about the structure. This goes for other board gamers as well, but I'd like to know if anyone who posted and said chess have any special memories of playing the game. In other words, is there anything more to peoples liking of it because of structure?

Chess is the best because it's challenging, tricky, enlightening and can be played by mail. I had a friend who moved to an adjacent state after being a chessmate for years. We played several matches by postcard by simply each having a full chess board and sending the moves by code on a postcard. The moves are quite easy to describe.
Ooaman you could of had scrabble as a choice BUT NOOO!!!! Go rich Uncle Penny Bags
Yep Scrabble first for me and then Chinese Checkers.

I think people are putting chess as the best (and not necessarily their personal favorite) because it really is the best. Uncle John's Bathroom Reader Plunges Into History (pg.325) says it best in their "Best List of Bests." It's a great list in general, so check it out.
 
 "Best Board Game: Chess, which was introduced to Europe at the beginning of the millennium. Why is it the best? Because no one gives a damn that a computer can beat a human at monopoly."
 
 I do have to say that I've played some of the games that were predecessors to chess including a Viking game the name of which I can't remember right now, which also were very fun.
 
 Although, while personally I do enjoy chess, I also love Trivial Pursuit, Risk, Clue, and just about any other.
